I shall quit your vessel on the ice raft which brought me thither and shall seek the most northern extremity of the globe; I shall collect my funeral pile and consume to ashes this miserable frame, that its remains may afford no light to any curious and unhallowed wretch who would create such another as I have been. I shall die. I shall no longer feel the agonies which now consume me or be the prey of feelings unsatisfied, yet unquenched. He is dead who called me into being; and when I shall be no more, the very remembrance of us both will speedily vanish. I shall no longer see the sun or stars or feel the winds play on my cheeks. Light, feeling, and sense will pass away; and in this condition must I find my happiness. Some years ago, when the images which this world affords first opened upon me, when I felt the cheering warmth of summer and heard the rustling of the leaves and the warbling of the birds, and these were all to me, I should have wept to die; now it is my only consolation. Polluted by crimes and torn by the bitterest remorse, where can I find rest but in death?

“Farewell! I leave you, and in you the last of humankind whom these eyes will ever behold. Farewell, Frankenstein! If thou wert yet alive and yet cherished a desire of revenge against me, it would be better satiated in my life than in my destruction. But it was not so; thou didst seek my extinction, that I might not cause greater wretchedness; and if yet, in some mode unknown to me, thou hadst not ceased to think and feel, thou wouldst not desire against me a vengeance greater than that which I feel. Blasted as thou wert, my agony was still superior to thine, for the bitter sting of remorse will not cease to rankle in my wounds until death shall close them for ever.

“But soon,” he cried with sad and solemn enthusiasm, “I shall die, and what I now feel be no longer felt. Soon these burning miseries will be extinct. I shall ascend my funeral pile triumphantly and exult in the agony of the torturing flames. The light of that conflagration will fade away; my ashes will be swept into the sea by the winds. My spirit will sleep in peace, or if it thinks, it will not surely think thus. Farewell.”

He sprang from the cabin-window as he said this, upon the ice raft which lay close to the vessel. He was soon borne away by the waves and lost in darkness and distance.

Chapter 24

My current situation was one in which all voluntary thought was swallowed up and lost. I was swept away by fury; revenge alone gave me strength and composure; it shaped my feelings and allowed me to be calculating and calm at times when otherwise delirium or death would have been my fate. My first resolution was to leave Geneva forever; my country, which had once been dear to me when I was happy and loved, had now become hateful in my adversity. I gathered a sum of money, along with a few jewels that belonged to my mother, and departed. Thus began my wanderings, which will only cease with my life. I have crossed vast portions of the earth and endured all the hardships that travelers in deserts and savage lands typically face. How I have survived, I hardly know; many times I have stretched my failing limbs upon the sandy plains and prayed for death. But revenge kept me alive; I dared not die and leave my adversary unpunished.

When I left Geneva, my first task was to find some clue to trace the steps of my fiendish enemy. But my plan was unsettled, and I wandered for many hours around the outskirts of the town, uncertain of which path to take. As night approached, I found myself at the entrance of the cemetery where William, Elizabeth, and my father lay. I entered and approached the tomb that marked their graves. Everything was silent except for the leaves of the trees, which rustled gently in the wind; the night was nearly dark, and the scene would have been solemn and moving even to an uninterested observer. The spirits of the departed seemed to flit around and cast a shadow, felt but unseen, over the head of the mourner. The deep grief that this scene initially stirred in me quickly transformed into rage and despair. They were dead, and I lived; their murderer also lived, and to destroy him, I must drag out my weary existence.

I knelt on the grass, kissed the earth, and with trembling lips exclaimed, “By the sacred ground on which I kneel, by the shades that wander near me, by the deep and eternal grief I feel, I swear; and by you, O Night, and the spirits that preside over you, to pursue the demon who caused this misery until he or I perish in mortal conflict. For this purpose, I will preserve my life; to execute this dear revenge, I will once again behold the sun and tread the green grass of the earth, which otherwise would vanish from my sight forever. And I call on you, spirits of the dead, and you, wandering ministers of vengeance, to aid and guide me in this task. Let the cursed and hellish monster drink deep of agony; let him feel the despair that now torments me.”

I had begun my vow with solemnity and an awe that almost assured me that the shades of my murdered friends heard and approved my devotion, but fury possessed me as I finished, and rage choked my words. I was answered through the stillness of the night by a loud and fiendish laugh. It rang in my ears for a long time; the mountains echoed it, and I felt as if all hell surrounded me with mockery and laughter. Surely in that moment, I should have been consumed by madness and destroyed my wretched existence, but my vow was heard, and I was destined for vengeance.

The laughter subsided when a familiar and hated voice, seemingly close to my ear, addressed me in an audible whisper, “I am satisfied, miserable wretch! You have chosen to live, and I am satisfied.” I rushed toward the source of the sound, but the devil eluded my grasp. Suddenly, the broad disk of the moon rose and shone fully upon his ghastly and distorted form as he fled with more than mortal speed. I pursued him, and for many months, this has been my task. Guided by a slight clue, I followed the winding course of the Rhone, but in vain.

The blue Mediterranean appeared, and by a strange chance, I saw the fiend enter a ship at night, hiding himself in a vessel bound for the Black Sea. I took passage on the same ship, but he escaped, I know not how. Amidst the wilds of Tartary and Russia, although he still evaded me, I have always followed his trail. Sometimes the peasants, frightened by this horrible apparition, informed me of his path; sometimes he himself, fearing that I would despair and die if I lost all trace of him, left some mark to guide me. The snows fell on my head, and I saw the imprint of his huge foot on the white plain.

To you, just beginning life, to whom care is new and agony unknown, how can you understand what I have felt and still feel? Cold, want, and fatigue were the least pains I was destined to endure; I was cursed by some devil and carried with me my eternal hell; yet still, a spirit of good followed and directed my steps, and when I most complained, it would suddenly extricate me from seemingly insurmountable difficulties. Sometimes, when nature, overcome by hunger, sank into exhaustion, a meal would be prepared for me in the desert, restoring and invigorating me. The food was indeed coarse, such as the peasants of the land ate, but I will not doubt that it was set there by the spirits I had invoked to aid me. Often, when all was dry, the heavens cloudless, and I was parched with thirst, a slight cloud would dim the sky, shed a few drops that revived me, and vanish.

I followed, when I could, the courses of the rivers; but the demon generally avoided these, as it was where the population of the country mainly collected. In other places, humans were rarely seen, and I generally subsisted on the wild animals that crossed my path. I had money with me and gained the friendship of the villagers by distributing it; or I brought with me some food that I had hunted, which, after taking a small portion, I always presented to those who had provided me with fire and cooking utensils. My life, as it passed, was indeed hateful to me, and it was only during sleep that I could taste joy. O blessed sleep! Often, when most miserable, I sank into repose, and my dreams lulled me even to rapture. The spirits that guarded me provided these moments, or rather hours, of happiness so that I might retain the strength to fulfill my pilgrimage. Deprived of this respite, I would have sunk under my hardships.

During the day, I was sustained and inspired by the hope of night, for in sleep, I saw my friends, my wife, and my beloved country; I again saw the kind face of my father, heard the sweet tones of Elizabeth’s voice, and beheld Clerval enjoying health and youth. Often, when wearied by a toilsome march, I convinced myself that I was dreaming until night fell, and I would then enjoy reality in the arms of my dearest friends. What agonizing affection I felt for them! How I clung to their dear forms, as sometimes they haunted even my waking hours, and persuaded myself that they still lived! At such moments, vengeance, that burned within me, died in my heart, and I pursued my path toward the destruction of the demon more as a task assigned to me by heaven, as the mechanical impulse of some unconscious power, than as the passionate desire of my soul.

What his feelings were, whom I pursued, I cannot know. Sometimes, indeed, he left marks in writing on the bark of the trees or carved in stone that guided me and fueled my fury. “My reign is not yet over”—these words were legible in one of these inscriptions—“you live, and my power is complete. Follow me; I seek the everlasting ice of the north, where you will feel the misery of cold and frost, to which I am indifferent. You will find near this place, if you do not follow too tardily, a dead hare; eat and be refreshed. Come on, my enemy; we have yet to wrestle for our lives, but many hard and miserable hours you must endure before that moment arrives.” Cursed devil! Again I vow vengeance; again I dedicate you, miserable fiend, to torture and death. Never will I give up my search until he or I perish; and then, with what ecstasy shall I join my Elizabeth and my departed friends, who even now prepare for me the reward of my tedious toil and horrible journey!

As I continued my journey northward, the snows thickened, and the cold became almost unbearable. The peasants were locked in their homes, and only a few of the hardiest ventured out to catch the animals driven from their hiding places by starvation. The rivers were covered with ice, and no fish could be caught; thus, I was cut off from my main source of sustenance. My enemy's triumph grew with the difficulty of my labors. One inscription he left read: “Prepare! Your struggles are only beginning; wrap yourself in furs and provide food, for we shall soon embark on a journey where your suffering will satisfy my everlasting hatred.”

My courage and perseverance were invigorated by these taunting words; I resolved not to fail in my purpose, and calling on Heaven for support, I continued with unwavering fervor to traverse immense deserts until the ocean appeared at a distance, forming the farthest boundary of the horizon. Oh! How unlike it was to the blue seas of the south! Covered with ice, it could only be distinguished from land by its greater wildness and ruggedness. The Greeks wept for joy when they beheld the Mediterranean from the hills of Asia, joyfully hailing the boundary of their toils. I did not weep, but I knelt down and, with a full heart, thanked my guiding spirit for leading me safely to the place where I hoped, despite my adversary's mockery, to meet and confront him.

A few weeks prior to this moment, I had procured a sled and dogs and thus crossed the snows with astonishing speed. I do not know whether the fiend had the same advantages, but I found that, whereas before I had lost ground in the pursuit, I was now gaining on him, so much so that when I first saw the ocean, he was only one day's journey ahead, and I hoped to intercept him before he reached the shore. With newfound courage, I pressed on, and in two days arrived at a miserable village on the seashore. I inquired of the inhabitants about the fiend and received accurate information. A gigantic monster, they said, had arrived the night before, armed with a gun and many pistols, frightening the residents of a solitary cottage with his terrifying appearance. He had carried off their winter food supply and, placing it in a sled, had harnessed a large number of trained dogs, and that same night, to the relief of the horrified villagers, had pursued his journey across the sea in a direction that led to no land; they conjectured that he would soon be destroyed by the breaking of the ice or frozen by the eternal frost.

Upon hearing this information, I suffered a brief bout of despair. He had escaped me, and I must begin a destructive and almost endless journey across the icy mountains of the ocean, through cold that few of the inhabitants could endure, and which I, a native of a warm and sunny climate, could not hope to survive. Yet at the thought of the fiend living and triumphant, my rage and vengeance returned, overwhelming every other feeling like a mighty tide. After a brief rest, during which the spirits of the dead hovered around, urging me to toil and seek revenge, I prepared for my journey. I exchanged my land sled for one designed for the uneven surface of the Frozen Ocean, and after purchasing a plentiful stock of provisions, I departed from land.

I cannot guess how many days have passed since then, but I have endured misery that nothing but the eternal sense of just retribution burning within my heart could have enabled me to withstand. Immense and rugged mountains of ice often blocked my way, and I often heard the thunder of the sea, which threatened my destruction. But again the frost came and made the paths of the sea secure. Based on the provisions I consumed, I estimate that I spent three weeks on this journey; and the continual extension of hope, returning back upon my heart, often wrung bitter drops of despondency and grief from my eyes. Despair had indeed almost secured her prey, and I would soon have sunk beneath this misery.

Once, after the poor animals that carried me had, with incredible effort, reached the summit of a sloping ice mountain, and one, succumbing to fatigue, died, I gazed at the expanse before me in anguish when suddenly my eye caught a dark speck on the dusky plain. I strained my vision to discern what it could be and let out a wild cry of ecstasy when I recognized a sled and the distorted form of someone I knew within. Oh! With what a burning rush did hope return to my heart! Warm tears filled my eyes, which I hastily wiped away so that they would not obstruct my view of the demon; but still my sight was blurred by the burning drops, until, succumbing to the overwhelming emotions, I wept aloud. But this was not the time for delay; I removed the dogs from their dead companion, gave them a generous portion of food, and after an hour's rest, which was absolutely necessary but bitterly irksome to me, I continued on my way.

The sled was still visible, and I did not lose sight of it again except for brief moments when some ice-rock concealed it behind its crags. I was indeed gaining on it, and when, after nearly two days of travel, I saw my enemy no more than a mile away, my heart soared within me. But now, just as I seemed almost within reach of my foe, my hopes were suddenly extinguished, and I lost all trace of him more completely than I ever had before. A ground sea was heard; the thunder of its approach, as the waters rolled and swelled beneath me, became increasingly ominous and terrifying. I pressed on, but in vain. The wind rose; the sea roared; and with a tremendous and overwhelming sound, like the mighty shock of an earthquake, it split and cracked.

The destruction was swift; in a few minutes, a tumultuous sea rolled between me and my enemy, leaving me drifting on a scattered piece of ice that was continually shrinking, preparing for me a hideous death. In this manner, many dreadful hours passed; several of my dogs died, and I myself was about to succumb under the weight of my misery when I saw your vessel anchored and offering me hopes of rescue and life. I had no idea that ships ever ventured this far north and was astonished at the sight. I quickly dismantled part of my sled to make oars, and with infinite effort, I was able to move my ice raft towards your ship. I had resolved that if you were heading south, I would still trust myself to the mercy of the seas rather than abandon my purpose. But your direction was northward. You took me aboard when my strength was exhausted, and I would soon have sunk under my multiplied hardships into a death that I still dread, for my task remains unfulfilled.

Oh! When will my guiding spirit, in leading me to the demon, allow me the rest I so desperately desire; or must I die, and he still live? If I do, swear to me, Walton, that he shall not escape, that you will seek him and satisfy my vengeance in his death. And do I dare to ask you to undertake my pilgrimage, to endure the hardships I have faced? No; I am not that selfish. Yet, when I am dead, if he should appear, if the ministers of vengeance should bring him to you, swear that he shall not live—swear that he shall not triumph over my accumulated woes and survive to add to the list of his dark crimes. He is eloquent and persuasive, and once his words even held power over my heart; but trust him not. His soul is as hellish as his form, full of treachery and fiendish malice. Do not listen to him; call on the names of William, Justine, Clerval, Elizabeth, my father, and the wretched Victor, and thrust your sword into his heart. I will hover nearby and direct the steel aright.

Walton, in continuation.

August 26th, 17—.

You have read this strange and terrifying story, Margaret; and do you not feel your blood run cold with horror, like that which even now curdles mine? Sometimes, seized with sudden agony, he could not continue his tale; at other times, his voice, broken yet piercing, uttered with difficulty the words filled with anguish. His fine and lovely eyes were now lit with indignation, now subdued to downcast sorrow and quenched in infinite misery. Sometimes he controlled his countenance and tones, relating the most horrible incidents with a tranquil voice, suppressing every sign of agitation; then, like a volcano erupting, his face would suddenly change to one of the wildest rage as he screamed imprecations at his persecutor. His tale is coherent and told with an appearance of the simplest truth, yet I confess to you that the letters of Felix and Safie, which he showed me, and the apparition of the monster seen from our ship, have given me a greater belief in the truth of his narrative than his assurances, however earnest and connected.

Such a monster really does exist! I cannot doubt it, yet I am lost in surprise and admiration. Sometimes I tried to extract from Frankenstein the details of his creature’s formation, but on this point, he was impenetrable. “Are you mad, my friend?” he said. “Or where does your senseless curiosity lead you? Would you also create for yourself and the world a demoniacal enemy? Peace, peace! Learn my miseries and do not seek to increase your own.”

Frankenstein discovered that I was taking notes about his history; he asked to see them and then corrected and augmented them in many places, particularly in giving life and spirit to the conversations he had with his enemy. “Since you have preserved my narration,” he said, “I would not have a mutilated version go down to posterity.” Thus has a week passed away while I have listened to the strangest tale ever imagined. My thoughts and every feeling of my soul have been absorbed by the interest for my guest that this tale and his elevated and gentle manners have created. I wish to soothe him, yet can I counsel one so infinitely miserable, so devoid of every hope of consolation, to live? Oh, no! The only joy he can know now will be when he finally composes his shattered spirit to peace and death.

Yet he enjoys one comfort, born of solitude and delirium; he believes that when he dreams he converses with his friends and derives from that communion consolation for his miseries or encouragement for his vengeance, that they are not mere figments of his imagination, but the beings themselves who visit him from a distant world.
